newsitem.title: GERMANY: Continental profits double in first half.
newsitem.headline: Continental profits double in first half.

text.p: Continental AG, Germany's largest tire maker, said Tuesday profits more than doubled in the first half of 1996 despite weakness in the German economy. It projected higher profits for the full year.

Continental, the world's fourth-largest tire manufacturer, said pretax profits rose to 120 million marks ($81 million) in the six months ended on June 30, from 58 million marks ($39 million) in the 1995 first half. It cited cost controls, increased productivity and favourable exchange rates.
Management board chairman Hubertus von Gruenberg had forecast a doubling of profits at the group's annual general meeting in June.
Continental, whose fortunes tend to mirror those of the German auto industry, said sales in the first half rose 1 percent to 5.09 billion marks ($3.44 billion) from 5.03 billion ($3.40 billion).
Earnings in its passenger car tire business saw above average growth, it said, as sales grew 1.2 percent to 1.93 billion marks ($1.30 billion).
Profits also improved in its truck tire operation, despite a 5.9 percent drop in sales to 550 million marks ($371 million).
Sales also fell at the company's Continental General Tire unit in the United States, but pretax profits improved in part because of restructuring moves.
The company had 46,974 employees at mid-year, off 3.6 percent from the same period last year, which helped keep costs under control.
